items.title: Cannot install npm in Windows 10
items.body:
when try to install with
`nodeenv --node=10.16.0 --npm=6.4.1 env`
I got the error "urllib.error.HTTPError: HTTP Error 404: Not Found"

seems that the zip file should have prefix "v"
my workaround:
i change the file nodeenv.py line 742 (inside **install_npm_win()**)
from 
`npm_url = 'https://github.com/npm/cli/archive/%s.zip' % opt.npm`
 to 
`npm_url = 'https://github.com/npm/cli/archive/v%s.zip' % opt.npm`

items.title: Feature: Store node_modules elsewhere
items.body:
As a python developer, it drives me mad to have `node_modules` clutter my root folder. We do not put our python `site-packages` in there either but cleanly store them away elsewhere.

_I am not sure it is in the scope of `nodeenv` to address this problem however it would be great if it did._

What I envision would be a feature that stores the node_modules somewhere in the `.venv` folder at the same time conserving all path resolutions. Thereby we could continue to use any node command such as `npm install` just as before.

One package aiming to achieve that goal is:
https://github.com/shadow-light/npmenv

However, I would not like to have both `nodeenv` and `npmenv` meddle with my environments paths fearing that it eventually breaks. Also `npmenv` in its current incarnation does not store the `node_modules` in `.venv`.

Options of `node` itself that are not workable are:
- Setting the `NODE_PATH` env variable -> Works only for global installs, paths break
- Using the `--prefix` flag -> Does not save installs to `package.json`, paths break

items.title: nodeenv error output for versions w/ a `v` prefix is suboptimal
items.body:
```
$ nodeenv --prebuilt  -n v10.15.2 node-v10.15.2
 * Install prebuilt node (v10.15.2) .Traceback (most recent call last):
```

Yes, the correct command should be `nodeenv --prebuilt  -n 10.15.2 node-v10.15.2`

I'm not interested in that. What bothers me is the `) .Traceback` output -- especially the apparently random placement of the `.`.

That currently comes from:
https://github.com/ekalinin/nodeenv/blob/a122f1857068d061e166c38b62640f6836efb3ef/nodeenv.py#L698
https://github.com/ekalinin/nodeenv/blob/a122f1857068d061e166c38b62640f6836efb3ef/nodeenv.py#L710
With the `Traceback` part being Python's standard traceback handling.

It seems to me that nodeenv could either handle this case gracefully (possibly by warning that it isn't expecting a `v` / or by explaining the 404 and providing the url it was looking at so someone could browse), or at the very least trap the exception and include a newline before spitting out `Traceback`....

Note that normally there are a bunch of `.`s as in:
```
$ nodeenv --prebuilt  -n 10.15.1 node-v10.15.1
 * Install prebuilt node (10.15.1) ..... done.
```
under which circumstances, the `.`s make sense as a form of progress. But for this early failure case, it just looks weird.

items.title: cspell package fails to install inside nodeenv but succeeds outside
items.body:
Initially I raised this bug at https://github.com/Jason3S/cspell/issues/53 but after it received a minor fix for `npm install -g .` command I am inclined to believe that this is a nodeenv specific bug now.

Reproducer:
```
pip install --user nodeenv
git clone https://github.com/Jason3S/cspell
cd cspell
nodeenv nenv
. nenv/bin/activate
npm install -g .
```

Be sure you run this on a clean clone, because otherwise if a build was performed and `dist/` folder was created and populated the install may succeed. Still, we need to be sure that installation would succeed without requiring extra preparatory steps, regardless of previous build being made inside the repository.

items.title: NPM unusable after nodeenv configured in clean python virtualenv
items.body:
Hi there,

Trying to use a Python VirtualEnv with nodeenv to keep installation dependencies within a single folder.

I followed the steps as best as I can, but there seems to be a fatal confusion about what folders contain what. For example if I run the following from a clean start...

```bash
cefn@cefn-artful-thinkpad:~$ mkdir testnodeenv
cefn@cefn-artful-thinkpad:~$ cd testnodeenv/
cefn@cefn-artful-thinkpad:~/testnodeenv$ ~/.local/bin/virtualenv .
cefn@cefn-artful-thinkpad:~/testnodeenv$ source bin/activate
(testnodeenv) cefn@cefn-artful-thinkpad:~/testnodeenv$ pip install nodeenv
(testnodeenv) cefn@cefn-artful-thinkpad:~/testnodeenv$ nodeenv -p
(testnodeenv) cefn@cefn-artful-thinkpad:~/testnodeenv$ source bin/activate
(testnodeenv) cefn@cefn-artful-thinkpad:~/testnodeenv$ npm install startbootstrap-blog-post
```

...then I get the following error, which prevents me from installing this simple bootstrap template repo (very few dependencies) and seems to come from the fact that npm is actually trying to access a global folder, not the virtualenv one ...

```bash
npm WARN enoent ENOENT: no such file or directory, open '/home/cefn/package.json'
npm WARN bootstrap@4.0.0 requires a peer of popper.js@^1.12.9 but none is installed. You must install peer dependencies yourself.
npm WARN cefn No description
npm WARN cefn No repository field.
npm WARN cefn No README data
npm WARN cefn No license field.

npm ERR! path /home/cefn/node_modules/npm/node_modules/dezalgo
npm ERR! code ENOENT
npm ERR! errno -2
npm ERR! syscall rename
npm ERR! enoent ENOENT: no such file or directory, rename '/home/cefn/node_modules/npm/node_modules/dezalgo' -> '/home/cefn/node_modules/npm/node_modules/.dezalgo.DELETE'
npm ERR! enoent This is related to npm not being able to find a file.
npm ERR! enoent 

npm ERR! A complete log of this run can be found in:
npm ERR!     /home/cefn/.npm/_logs/2018-04-02T14_02_42_765Z-debug.log
```

I get the same error when trying to install something as mainstream as jquery-browserify so I don't think it's related to the package, but rather to the paths managed by nodeenv hence I am reporting it here.

Could this be related to the fact Ubuntu doesn't place Pip binaries by default on the console $PATH? 
( https://bugs.launchpad.net/ubuntu/+source/bash/+bug/1588562 )

There is indeed a dezalgo package within the virtualenv...

```bash
(testnodeenv) cefn@cefn-artful-thinkpad:~/testnodeenv$ find . -iname '*dezalgo*'
./src/node-v9.10.1-linux-x64/lib/node_modules/npm/node_modules/dezalgo
./src/node-v9.10.1-linux-x64/lib/node_modules/npm/node_modules/dezalgo/dezalgo.js
./lib/node_modules/npm/node_modules/dezalgo
./lib/node_modules/npm/node_modules/dezalgo/dezalgo.js
```

...but npm is looking for it wrongly in /home/cefn/node_modules/npm/node_modules/dezalgo for some kind of path misconfiguration reason.

You can see the full npm log as suggested by the error message at https://gist.github.com/cefn/e94d35514055186f34e9ebbbf3a840cf

items.title: wrong URL node binaries on arm64
items.body:
Creating a nodeenv is currently not possible on an arm64 machine (Rock64 +Ubuntu bionic) because the generated download link for the binary is wrong.

It tries to download from 
```
https://nodejs.org/dist/v9.10.0/node-v9.10.0-linux-armv64.tar.gz
```

But the correct link is 
```
 https://nodejs.org/dist/v9.10.0/node-v9.10.0-linux-arm64.tar.gz
```

See: http://nodejs.org/dist/ I think it is safe to just remove the "v" from https://github.com/ekalinin/nodeenv/blob/master/nodeenv.py#L511 since v4.0.0 this looks like the filename pattern...

items.body:
Easiest reproduction is through using `alpine` with docker.

```console
$ docker run -ti python:2.7.14-alpine3.7 sh -exc 'pip install nodeenv; nodeenv nenv; . nenv/bin/activate; node --version'

Collecting nodeenv
  Downloading nodeenv-1.2.0.tar.gz
Building wheels for collected packages: nodeenv

  Stored in directory: /root/.cache/pip/wheels/6c/b7/e4/5073762ef06303f9f9e24a9640e049843ddd4ac0d6842e308b
Successfully built nodeenv
Installing collected packages: nodeenv
Successfully installed nodeenv-1.2.0
+ nodeenv nenv
 * Install prebuilt node (9.5.0) ..... done.
+ . nenv/bin/activate
+ deactivate_node nondestructive
+ [ -n  ]
+ [ -n  -o -n  ]
+ [ -n  ]
+ unset NODE_VIRTUAL_ENV
+ [ ! nondestructive = nondestructive ]
+ [  ]
+ NODE_VIRTUAL_ENV=/nenv
+ export NODE_VIRTUAL_ENV
+ _OLD_NODE_VIRTUAL_PATH=/usr/local/bin:/usr/local/sbin:/usr/local/bin:/usr/sbin:/usr/bin:/sbin:/bin
+ PATH=/nenv/lib/node_modules/.bin:/nenv/bin:/usr/local/bin:/usr/local/sbin:/usr/local/bin:/usr/sbin:/usr/bin:/sbin:/bin
+ export PATH
+ _OLD_NODE_PATH=
+ NODE_PATH=/nenv/lib/node_modules
+ export NODE_PATH
+ _OLD_NPM_CONFIG_PREFIX=
+ _OLD_npm_config_prefix=
+ NPM_CONFIG_PREFIX=/nenv
+ npm_config_prefix=/nenv
+ export NPM_CONFIG_PREFIX
+ export npm_config_prefix
+ [ -z  ]
+ _OLD_NODE_VIRTUAL_PS1=\w \$ 
+ [ x(nenv) != x ]
+ PS1=(nenv)\w \$ 
+ export PS1
+ [ -n  -o -n  ]
+ node --version
sh: node: not found
```

A workaround (I believe... it's still building) is to build from source:

```bash
apk --no-cache add gcc g++ make linux-headers
nodeenv nenv --source  # wait for an eternity
```

Originally reported here: https://github.com/pre-commit/mirrors-jshint/issues/4

I wonder if we can ignore prebuilt linux binaries if we're not using glibc?

items.title: tox.ini should be included in the default configuration files that are checked

items.title: --force doesn't downgrade an existing nodeenv, only upgrades.
items.body:
I'm attempting to create a new nodeenv using Node 6.9.4 where an existing Node 7.4.0 nodeenv is on the disk. The expected behavior is that after running `nodeenv <path> --node=6.9.4 --force`, `<path>/bin/node --version` would return 6.9.4. However, instead I see the following behavior:

```
$> nodeenv --version
1.1.0
$> rm -rf foo
$> nodeenv foo --node=6.9.4 --prebuilt --force
 * Install prebuilt node (6.9.4) ..... done.
$> foo/bin/node --version
v6.9.4
$> nodeenv foo --node=7.4.0 --prebuilt --force
 * Environment already exists: foo
 * Install prebuilt node (7.4.0) ..... done.
$> foo/bin/node --version
v7.4.0
$> nodeenv foo --node=6.9.4 --prebuilt --force
 * Environment already exists: foo
 * Install prebuilt node (6.9.4) ..... done.
$> foo/bin/node --version
v7.4.0
```

That is, the node version stays at 7.4.0 after creating a new nodeenv using `--force` and version 6.9.4 at that path.

Interestingly, `--force` seems to upgrade the node version just fine when the new nodeenv is created (from 6.9.4 to 7.4.0) but won't downgrade it.

cc @gsong

items.title: nodeenv try to download non existing tar.gz prebuilt under Cygwin
items.body:
Hi,

I think this project used to support Cygwin, is this still the case ?

I'm having an issue with the following command:
```
nodeenv --prebuilt tmp
```
The error is the following:
```
urllib2.HTTPError: HTTP Error 404: Not Found
```
The `tar.gz` it tries to install is https://nodejs.org/dist/v7.2.1/node-v7.2.1-cygwin_nt-6.1-x64.tar.gz, which does not exist. My guess is that `nodeenv` should use the Windows prebuilts instead: https://nodejs.org/dist/v7.2.1/node-v7.2.1-win-x64.zip
This is because `platform.system()` is used: https://github.com/ekalinin/nodeenv/blob/master/nodeenv.py#L503

I faced this problem while using `pre-commit` : https://github.com/pre-commit/pre-commit/issues/455

Could `nodeenv` uses the Windows prebuilt when invoked under Cygwin ?

items.title: Launchpad PPA packaging
items.body:
@ekalinin Created a Launchpad project for daily builds of this project:
https://code.launchpad.net/~sgnn7/+archive/ubuntu/nodeenv

Sadly 2 problems here:
- https://bugs.launchpad.net/bzr-builder/+bug/1432282. Since `debian-upstream` is in same branch and I can't rename the dir in a recipe, I need separate branch/repo for the packaging. I created my own at https://github.com/sgnn7/nodeenv-launchpad-packaging but having a `debian` branch or moving the folder `debian-upstream` to `debian` would be better since the current way requires manual pushes to update the packaging.
- Only 0.8+ `dh-virtualenv` packages on Launchpad are for Trusty/Utopic but I can only specify Trusty as the target so only one distribution build. This would require builing for ther distro versions by the owners of that PPA.

Let me know if you want something else done with this.

items.title: nodeenv is not allowed to download iojs
items.body:
Hi,

When I try to install iojs vie nodeenv, I get this stack trace:

```
 * Install iojs (1.8.1Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "ann/admin/venv/bin/nodeenv", line 9, in <module>
    load_entry_point('nodeenv==0.13.3', 'console_scripts', 'nodeenv')()
  File "ann/admin/venv/local/lib/python2.7/site-packages/nodeenv.py", line 883, in main
    create_environment(env_dir, opt)
  File "ann/admin/venv/local/lib/python2.7/site-packages/nodeenv.py", line 724, in create_environment
    install_node(env_dir, src_dir, opt)
  File "ann/admin/venv/local/lib/python2.7/site-packages/nodeenv.py", line 593, in install_node
    download_node(node_url, src_dir, env_dir, opt)
  File "ann/admin/venv/local/lib/python2.7/site-packages/nodeenv.py", line 489, in download_node
    tar_contents = io.BytesIO(urlopen(node_url).read())
  File "/usr/lib/python2.7/urllib2.py", line 154, in urlopen
    return opener.open(url, data, timeout)
  File "/usr/lib/python2.7/urllib2.py", line 437, in open
    response = meth(req, response)
  File "/usr/lib/python2.7/urllib2.py", line 550, in http_response
    'http', request, response, code, msg, hdrs)
  File "/usr/lib/python2.7/urllib2.py", line 475, in error
    return self._call_chain(*args)
  File "/usr/lib/python2.7/urllib2.py", line 409, in _call_chain
    result = func(*args)
  File "/usr/lib/python2.7/urllib2.py", line 558, in http_error_default
    raise HTTPError(req.get_full_url(), code, msg, hdrs, fp)
urllib2.HTTPError: HTTP Error 403: Forbidden
```

Analyzing the network traffic, I see that we are trying to do an HTTP request for  http://iojs.org/dist/v1.8.1/iojs-v1.8.1-linux-x64.tar.gz, and we get a 403.

Looking at the body of the 403 message, I can extract this information:
- Access denied | iojs.org used CloudFlare to restrict access
- The owner of this website (iojs.org) has banned your access based on your browser's signature (21d0f4c3229b0aa2-ua48).

The way I interpret this, it looks like (until the iojs.org guys change their settings) it will be impossible to install iojs using nodeenv. (Or whichever library, that was responsible for generating this "browser signature".) 

However, downloading iojs with (for example) wget works just fine....

Do you have any idea where this "browser signature" thing comes from? Or why the iojs guys decided to forbid downloads from nodeenv?

Thank you for the help!

items.title: nodeenv --list is raising TypeError
items.body:
When installed globally with `sudo pip install nodeenv`, `nodeenv --list` raises an exception.

This is due to `pkg_resources.parse_version` method having different return types in older versions. 

![nodeenv_bug](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/6031925/6599860/d253a2b0-c814-11e4-94d6-9a9d79cdf27c.png)

Possible hotfix solutions are:
- write a helper function to parse strings,
- write our own Version type :-1: 

But atm I'm working on finding out which version of `setuptools` introduced the newer (currently used in master) Version type that parses version strings and rely on it if `setuptools` is >= that version.

I'll combine that with one of two approaches:
- the raw string representation we get with regex pattern. However ascending sorting will be `0.1.0, 0.10.0, 0.9.0`,
-  the before mentioned helper function

I think broken ascending sort is acceptable as a hotfix.

PR will be submitted soon-ish. :8ball:

items.title: Warn about prefx in .npmrc
items.body:
I've just spent a little while getting confused about why my `npm install -g` commands where installing to another virtualenv despite being in a nodeenv enabled virtualenv. It turns out I had a `.npmrc` file with a `prefix` entry pointing at another virtualenv. I suspect it was my solution before I found `nodeenv`.

I realise that nodeenv code doesn't run during a general `npm install -g` but maybe when doing the `nodeenv -p` (which I re-did in an attempt to clean out and start again) it could warn about a `prefix` value in your `.npmrc` if that is going to disrupt the expected behaviour of the `nodeenv` setup?

Just a thought, thanks for an excellent project. I'm new to the node.js world and, being more familiar with Python, I was happy to see nodeenv :)

Michael

items.title: Symlink local module tree to the (virtualized) global one?
items.body:
In the nodeenv, having the difference betwen local (./node_modules) and global (./lib/node_modules) npm installation is pretty much pointless. Thus, adding  a symlink "node_modules → lib/node_modules" might make sense.

It certainly would make installation of things like gulp easier, which you have to install both globally and locally (for whatever reason).

items.title: repeated lines added to bin/activate
items.body:
I've mentioned this as a footnote on issue #43.
If for some reason, you run `nodeenv` more than once, then you end up with duplicated (or triplicated, or...) code on `bin/activate`, once for each time you ran the command.
At least, that's what happens when you create the nodeenv inside `virtualenv` (which, as far as I understand, in that case, both virtualenv and nodeenv share the same file for `activate` command). Not sure if this issue happens when creating a nodeenv outside a virtualenv.

Could it be a solution to keep the nodeenv code in a `activate_nodeenv` file and then `source` it inside virtualenv's `activate`?

items.title: why "freeze" command only outputs global packages?
items.body:
Hi. I'm trying to understand the rationale on the `freeze` command only freezing globally installed modules.
I get that nodeenv is useful mainly for installing packages in a virtual node environment in a global fashion. But what about packages installed locally (in a node_modules/) folder?

I'm fairly new to all things virtualenv/nodeenv, so there may be a good reason for only listing global packages when using the nodeenv "freeze" command, but on the other hand, I think I may find it useful to be able to freeze locally installed requirements.

items.title: Python 2.6 issue
items.body:
Thank you for your work on this wonderful tool. I just discovered it and it has made my life easier in countless ways! (I can finally have Node.js and Django code side-by-side for web projects without pulling my hair out.)

My shop standardizes on RHEL 6.4, which still uses Python 2.6 (we're moving to Python 2.7 as soon as RHEL 7 is available). Python 2.6 still uses a Tuple for sys.version_info, which causes a failure at line 414 of nodeenv.py. This can be fixed by using a getattr and supplying a default. See the code below (line 414):

``` python
...
if getattr(sys.version_info, 'major', sys.version_info[0]) > 2:
...
```

items.title: Create node executable shim in nodeenv's bin/ in case system node is used
items.body:
Hi,

some of our people prefer using virtualenv without activating environment with `activate` script — by adjusting `PATH` env var or by referencing executables directly in venv's `bin/`.

I think this is worth supporting and currently I do this via putting the following script into `bin/` during creating nodeenv:

```
#!/bin/sh
export NODE_PATH=/path/to/nodeenv/lib/node_modules
export NPM_CONFIG_PREFIX=/path/to/nodeenv
exec /path/to/system/installed/node $*
```

What do you think of this?

items.title: npm fails if $HOME is not set properly
items.body:
Running as a user without a home directory "npm install" fails.

I'm using a python virtualenv for a server I wrote. Now the need for nodejs arose, to build an optimized version of my javascripts using requirejs and uglyfyjs.
The user of the virtualenv at the production box is "myserver". "myserver" has no home directory at /home/myserver or elsewhere.

I installed nodejs in the python virtualenv using nodeenv as documented. This worked well.

But `npm install` failed:

```
$ npm install -g requirejs
npm ERR! Error: Attempt to unlock requirejs, which hasn't been locked
... a lot more text ...
```

`$HOME` is set to `/nonexistent`

```
$ echo $HOME
/nonexistent
```

My fix was to set the $HOME var (as the user myserver):

```
$ mkdir /path/to/virtualenv/home
$ HOME=/path/to/virtualenv/home
```

`npm install` now works.

Maybe the need for a home directory could be documented somwhere.

items.title: Freeze Regex sometimes extracts incorrect module & version number
items.body:
Hey, great project. Love it. I just started using it and I noticed an issue with the freeze command. Specifically if I run this initial part of the freeze regex: ``` npm ls -g | grep -E '^.{4}\w{1}' ``` I'll get reasonable top-level packages: 
├─┬ bower@1.2.8
├─┬ generator-angular@0.7.1
├─┬ generator-karma@0.6.0
├─┬ grunt@0.4.2
├─┬ grunt-cli@0.1.11
├─┬ grunt-karma@0.6.2
├─┬ karma@0.10.9
├── karma-chrome-launcher@0.1.2
├─┬ karma-coffee-preprocessor@0.1.2
├── karma-firefox-launcher@0.1.3
├── karma-html2js-preprocessor@0.1.0
├── karma-jasmine@0.1.5
├─┬ karma-phantomjs-launcher@0.1.1
├── karma-requirejs@0.2.1
├── karma-script-launcher@0.1.0
├─┬ npm@1.3.21
├─┬ phantomjs@1.9.2-6
├── requirejs@2.1.9
├─┬ socket.io@0.9.16
└─┬ yo@1.1.1
Once I add the regex that gets the version numbers: ``` npm ls -g | grep -E '^.{4}\w{1}' | grep -o -E '[a-zA-Z0-9\-]+@[0-9]+\.[0-9]+\.[0-9]+' ``` Notice what happens to "socket.io" as well as the phantomjs version number 
bower@1.2.8
generator-angular@0.7.1
generator-karma@0.6.0
grunt@0.4.2
grunt-cli@0.1.11
grunt-karma@0.6.2
karma@0.10.9
karma-chrome-launcher@0.1.2
karma-coffee-preprocessor@0.1.2
karma-firefox-launcher@0.1.3
karma-html2js-preprocessor@0.1.0
karma-jasmine@0.1.5
karma-phantomjs-launcher@0.1.1
karma-requirejs@0.2.1
karma-script-launcher@0.1.0
npm@1.3.21
phantomjs@1.9.2   # -6 stripped
requirejs@2.1.9
io@0.9.16  #socket stripped
yo@1.1.1
Then trying to reuse this requirements file in another venv causes 404s. The workaround is to manually edit the requirements file after performing a freeze. Perhaps a simpler regex should be used that simply splits on the @ character? I don't know enough about npm versions to comment on an appropriate fix.

items.title: Allow creation of new nodeenv in pre-existing directory
items.body:
Is it possible to allow installation of a nodeenv within an existing directory?  My use-case seems common -- to be able to git clone some Node project, cd into its directory, and create a nodeenv to start working in a clean, self-contained environment.

My current workaround is piggy-back on a Python virtualenv with:

```
virtualenv .
. ./bin/activate
nodeenv -p
```

which works, but it would be nice to be able to run `nodeenv .` and avoid the need to create a Python virtualenv.

items.title: --node=system won't work if there's already a compiled node on the virtualenv
items.body:
This may not be a bug per-se, but I've found this: on a virtualenv, if you first run `nodeenv -p`, it will download, compile and install a copy of `node` on `~/.virtualenvs/myproject/bin`. So far, so good.

But later, if you decide to use the system-wide `node` install, running `nodeenv -p --node=system` won't help you (nor running `nodeenv--node=system`, without the `-p` option).
The standard output will tell you that some changes are applied to `~/.virtualenvs/myproject/bin/activate` and it may even install npm, but the compiled `node` will be still there in `~/.virtualenvs/myproject/bin/`, and a `which node` will tell you that that's the `node` that will be used.

In other words, the `--node=system` didn't take any effect, and one could say that it "failed silently".

BTW, as a side-effect of running `nodeenv -p` a few times, I noticed that the same lines are n-plicated inside `~/.virtualenvs/myproject/bin/activate`. I don't know if there is a "cure" for that, but just letting you know. I manually cleaned the n-plicated lines.

items.title: Broken for latest node.js release 0.10.0
items.body:
The problem is this if block in get_node_src_url:

```
if version > "0.5.0":
    node_url = 'http://nodejs.org/dist/v%s/%s' % (version, tar_name)
else:
    node_url = 'http://nodejs.org/dist/%s' % (tar_name)
```

The above evaluates to False for 0.10.0. A better option might be to use parse_version from pkg_resources (distutils) and change this to 

```
if parse_version(version) > parse_version("0.5.0"):
    node_url = 'http://nodejs.org/dist/v%s/%s' % (version, tar_name)
else:
    node_url = 'http://nodejs.org/dist/%s' % (tar_name)
```

as per this stackoverflow answer: http://stackoverflow.com/a/6972866
